note: Small cursive Insular pointed minuscule which resembles Wearmouth/Jarrow Phase II minuscule of the compact rounded / tending to pointed variety introduced in the Moore Bede in the 740s-750s. There is a dedication cross at the top left of fol. 25, a feature found in Insular scriptural manuscripts from Wearmouth-Jarrow, and their derivatives, in the 8th century. The display capitals with multi-coloured infills and backgrounds (including a slate blue typical of the Mercian Tiberius group), however, resemble Mercian Tiberius group work of c. 800 (seen in Bodleian Hatton 93). The initial E formed of a Persian senmurv (a beast incorporating animal, bird, and fish features) on fol. 15v is of oriental style, with a ‘puzzle’ body recalling Frankish work but with a 'brontosaurus beast' Mercian Tiberius group animal head, reminiscent of those found in the Barberini Gospels and the Book of Cerne around 800-830. A senmurv also appears as a zoomorphic initial in the Mercian Royal Prayerbook (BL, Royal 2.A.xx) of c. 800. The style of script recalls Mercian Tiberius group mss of c. 800 also in the pointed aspect. This mixture of influences is typical of Latin manuscripts from Sinai which were probably made there. This is probably part of the same Insular Gospel book as that found on fols. 15, 19, 25r, 26 and 27 (Brown)

The remaining fragments indicate that this was a bifolium from a small format Gospel book of Insular pocket type. Its layout is somewhat squat, inclining to square rather than rectangular page layout, which is unusual in western manuscripts (but not eastern) (Brown)
